repnme.cdata!:
Guyana - Financial Sector and Business
            Environment Credit, Private Sector Development Adjustment
            Credit, and,  Financial and Private Sector Institutional
            Development Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The audit gives mixed results in rating
            the three operations, concurring, or not with the
            Implementation Completion (ICR) reports' ratings, as
            follows. It downgrades the Financial Sector and Business
            Environment (FSBEP) Project outcome to unsatisfactory, its
            sustainability to unlikely, institutional development
            impacts to negligible, including both Bank and Borrower
            performances to unsatisfactory; similarly, the Private
            Sector Development Adjustment Credit (PSDAC) is downgraded
            to moderately satisfactory outcomes, unlikely
            sustainability, modest institutional development impacts,
            satisfactory Bank performance, although concurs with a
            satisfactory Borrower performance; and, ratings on the
            Financial and Private Sector Institutional Development
            (FPSIDP) are also downgraded to unsatisfactory project
            outcomes, unlikely sustainability, and negligible
            institutional development impacts, yet, concurs with
            satisfactory performances by the Bank and Borrower. Some of
            the main lessons from these projects suggest that: The
            ethnic divide, distrust, and governance problems, are the
            key constraints to improving the environment for private
            sector development (PSD), and fostering sustainable growth
            in Guyana. At the project level, all future Bank operations,
            including their components and processes (e.g. consultations
            on project design, hiring of consultants, procurement,
            selection of trainees, choice of regulatory options, etc.),
            should address the way to at least, avoid deepening
            distrust, and if possible, serve to build trust across the
            racial divide. Transparency should be the key watchword for
            both the Government, and donors. In addition, more
            diagnostic work on incentives, institutions, and social
            capital is needed, with a view to identifying strategies,
            and tactics for rationalizing incentives, building
            sustainable institutions, and fostering social capital.
            Understanding the political economy is essential to project
            choice, and design.

repnme.cdata!:
Guyana - Private Sector Development
            Adjustment Credit

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Private Sector
            Development Adjustment Credit Project for Guyana were as
            follows: outcomes were satisfactory, International
            Development Association (IDA) performance during
            identification and preparation was highly satisfactory, and
            Borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: in the fiscal reform area, the implementation of
            tax reductions and minimum corporate taxes needs to more
            carefully take into account the effects on fiscal revenues,
            and the tax base, particularly for debt-ridden countries.
            The corporate tax reduction under the project, while meant
            to spur development and investment by the private sector,
            could only be implemented as long as the economy was growing
            at a rapid pace, and the government's fiscal position
            was improving. Following an International Monetary Fund
            (IMF) recommendation mid-way through the project, that the
            country's fiscal situation necessitated an additional
            revenue effort, the continued reduction in corporate taxes
            was halted in order to maintain the fiscal accounts in
            check. On the private sector side, the implementation of the
            minimum tax had to be waived, given that many manufacturing
            companies, who were operating on credit, did not have the
            cash flow to pay any tax at all. Thus, in future operations
            which target fiscal incentives for improving private
            investment, these reforms should be linked to underlying
            economic conditions with appropriate benchmark indicators.
            This will allow for realistic adjustments in policy targets
            of this type, these can be indexed to revenue ratios,
            especially when they are largely impacted by exogenous
            economic factors.
